conclusion: Use Faraday's law to calculate induced EMF, which is proportional to the rate of change of magnetic flux.
Magnetic flux through the coil is given by Œ¶_B = B * A * cos(Œ∏).
B = 0.1 T is the magnetic induction intensity.
A is the area of the rectangular coil.
Œ∏ is the angle between the normal to the coil and the magnetic field.
Area A of the rectangular coil is 0.1 m¬≤.
Coil rotates uniformly about axis OO' with angular velocity œâ = 100œÄ rad/s.
Angle Œ∏ changes with time as Œ∏ = œât.
Magnetic flux becomes Œ¶_B = 0.01 * cos(100œÄt) Wb.
Induced EMF is given by Faraday's law: ùìî = -n * dŒ¶_B/dt.
n = 100 is the number of turns of the coil.
Derivative of Œ¶_B with respect to t is -œÄ * sin(100œÄt) Wb/s.
Magnitude of the induced EMF is |ùìî| = 100œÄ * |sin(100œÄt)| V.
Maximum value of |sin(100œÄt)| is 1, so maximum induced EMF is 100œÄ V.
Magnitude of the induced electromotive force in the coil is 100œÄ V.
